poem:
### Corrections and Clarifications

Ink-blotted mornings,  
names tangled in type—  
Rob, Bob, Robinson.  
Ciphers in shadows,  
faces misplaced,  
where truth wears a mask.  
Figures shift like wind,  
caught in paper trees.  
We read, we err,  
unweaving twisted tales,  
where echoes of confusion  
meet the click of  
keys correcting whispers.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Corrections and clarifications • An article (Woman reveals toll of ‘coercive’ relationship with police spy, 20 November, p18) referred to an undercover police officer who used the fake name Rob Harrison. However, the accompanying image was of another undercover officer, real name Bob Lambert, who used the alias Bob Robinson. This error was in print only. •​ Owing to an editing error, an article about the home of the nature writer Ronald Blythe included some". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
